div.p: NARRATOR: These people all have different levels of biological risk, or trigger levels. Remember the higher the level of biological risk, the lower the trigger level.

NARRATOR: The first person has no known biological risk factors for increased risk. They have no family history and do not have a high tolerance. We could think of their trigger level as being standard or average.
NARRATOR: The second person has increased biological risk, maybe one close relative with alcoholism or drug addiction. We could think of this increased risk as a lower trigger level.
NARRATOR: The third person has multiple family members with alcoholism or addiction. So it is likely this person has a very low trigger level.
NARRATOR: In addition to their individual trigger levels, each person was born with an initial tolerance level.
NARRATOR: Tolerance levels vary from person to person. Here the lower line represents tolerance level.
NARRATOR: People who have a standard trigger level tend to also have a standard tolerance level.
NARRATOR: Remember from the research we just reviewed, people who have a lower trigger level are likely to have a higher tolerance level.
NARRATOR: And those with an even lower trigger level tend to have an even higher tolerance level.
NARRATOR: The principles are going to be the same for alcohol or drugs, but to make it simple, let's use alcohol as an example.
NARRATOR: People become impaired when they drink a high-risk quantity that exceeds t1eir tolerance level.
NARRATOR: Using these three people as examples, you can see that this person has the highest tolerance level.
NARRATOR: They are the one who will be able to drink the most before becoming impaired and they probably feel particularly good about their ability to really "handle" alcohol.
NARRATOR: But there's a catch. This person also has the lowest trigger level. In other words, this person is likely to develop alcoholism more quickly with high-risk drinking.
NARRATOR: Let's look at these three over time. Assume all three typically drink until they are impaired.
NARRATOR: This means they are all at risk for impairment problems. But, another danger is that their tolerance levels will increase.
NARRATOR: There is an important difference between a person's trigger level and their tolerance level. A person's trigger level for alcoholism or drug addiction is quite stable.
NARRATOR: Extreme stress or trauma may alter the addiction threshold, but there is little we can do to change it.
NARRATOR: On the other hand, the tolerance level can and does change, depending on how much a person drinks or uses.
NARRATOR: Each time a person drinks or uses drugs past their tolerance level, they not only become impaired, they also raise their tolerance level.
NARRATOR: If they continue drinking or using to the point of impairment, their tolerance level will increase again.
NARRATOR: As we can see here, after making high-risk choices over a period of time, the third person has already passed their trigger level, and has developed alcoholism or drug addiction.
NARRATOR: As they continue to make high-risk choices, their tolerance levels will continue to go up.
NARRATOR: Now, the second person's tolerance level is also high enough for them to drink enough to exceed their trigger level. Now, this person also has alcoholism.

NARRATOR: Finally, if the first person continues to make high-risk drinking choices, they will raise their tolerance level to the point at which they too can drink enough to pass their trigger level, alcoholism will be triggered.
NARRATOR: This can happen even thought this person did not start out with increased biological risk.
NARRATOR: So here we see the dangers of increased tolerance. When people drink to the point of impairment, they face increased risk for an impairment problem.
NARRATOR: But, when they drink to the point of impairment often enough, they force their tolerance up.
NARRATOR: And the increased tolerance makes it possible for each of these people to drink enough to pass their trigger levels for alcoholism.
NARRATOR: Most of us think of high tolerance as a sign of strength or as an abilityâ€” the ability to drink more.
NARRATOR: But this research makes it clear that high tolerance is actually a liability. In medical terms, it's a risk factor.
NARRATOR: Unfortunately, high tolerance looks like protection in the beginning because the person can drink so much before becoming impaired.
NARRATOR: However, it's clearly an indicator of increased risk, not decreased risk.
NARRATOR: Just as there is a trigger level for alcoholism or drug addiction, there is a trigger level for many other alcohol- or drug-related health problems.
NARRATOR: So, a person may pass their trigger level for alcohol-induced heart disease, cancer, pancreatitis, or cirrhosis, even if they have not yet triggered alcoholism or addiction.
NARRATOR: Along the way, they may also experience a number of impairment problems such as arrests, injuries, or damaged relationships.
